title: How to Write a School Novel for Teens

steps.headline: Research names or think up a name that is not used a lot in books for your characters.
steps.description: At the same time, you don't want your name to be completely ridiculous, so look for a good balance.

steps.headline: Determine your characters.
steps.description: Look at the cliques at your school to help you at. Try not to follow stereotypes, though: it's okay to have a jock who loves to read or a depressed cheerleader. Sometimes, it helps if you draw them (or get a picture online) and write a short summary of their personality so you get a feel for them.

steps.headline: Choose a setting.
steps.description: Maybe it's an all-girls private school, or a school for 'troubled children.' You also will need a name for the school: you can name it after a famous person (Abraham Lincoln High), the town (Hollywood Academy for the Preforming Arts), or a made-up person (Jessica Sydney High School).

steps.headline: Come up with a general idea in your head.
steps.description: Don't go in without an escape route - some vague idea of how or where you want the book to end up. At least know the sub-genre: drama, romance, action? Fantasy?

steps.headline: Commence writing.
steps.description: Your first sentences should hook the reader. By the first or second chapter, you should have revealed a little bit about the main character and a little bit of the school. A chapter can be anywhere from a page to thirty pages - whatever you do best.

steps.headline: Add a major drama or conflict.
steps.description: Maybe the main character lost her popularity due to a rumor; maybe she was framed for some rule-breaking. Keep it original, but also believable. Ask yourself: could I see this happening in my school?

steps.headline: Resolve the conflict, preferably in some unexpected way.
steps.description: If you plan on writing a second book, you can leave loose ends or cliffhangers, which is a suspenseful ending, in the last pages.

steps.headline: Get someone who you know very well to read your work.
steps.description: A good friend, English teacher, older sibling or someone else you're close to would be a good choice.

steps.headline: Reread and edit!
steps.description: You can do this yourself, or ask someone you know (see above) to help you, or both.

steps.headline: If you want to, try to get it published.
steps.description: The book Eragon was written by a fifteen year old boy. At the same time, remember that publication is a tricky business and it takes an undefinable amount of effort just to get someone to look at your manuscript.
